question.title: Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
question.body:
Resolves **Yes** if one of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:

 - Donald Trump
 - Donald Trump Jr.
 - Eric Trump
 - Ivanka Trump
 - Tiffany Trump
 - Melania Trump
 - Barron Trump

metadata.background_info:
Donald John Trump is the 45th and current president of the United States. Before entering politics, he was a businessman and television personality. Trump won a surprise victory in the [2016 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_United_States_presidential_election), and sought re-election in the [2020 presidential election.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election)

The [Trump family](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Family_of_Donald_Trump) has a net worth reported to be in the single-digit billions, and is now one of the most prominent families in Republican politics. Trump has several adult children, and there is speculation that a Trump political dynasty may emerge in the coming years, with both [Donald Trump Jr. and Ivanka Trump suggested as possible contenders for the presidency.](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/jan/04/donald-trump-jr-ivanka-trump-2024-presidential-election-poll)

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of the current date, Donald Trump has announced his candidacy for the 2024 Presidential election and remains a prominent figure within the Republican Party. He has a strong base of support and has maintained significant influence over the party. Given his previous success in securing the Republican nomination in 2016 and his continued political activities, it is plausible that he could secure the nomination again for 2024. 

Donald Trump Jr. and other members of the Trump family have not announced any intention to run for the presidency in 2024. While they have some visibility and influence, none have the same level of political experience or established support base within the party as Donald Trump. 

Considering these factors, the likelihood of Donald Trump being the Republican nominee is relatively high compared to other family members. However, there are still variables such as potential legal challenges, health issues, or shifts in political dynamics that could impact his candidacy. 

Overall, given Donald Trump's current position and the lack of other family members pursuing the nomination, the probability of a Trump family member being the nominee is mainly tied to Donald Trump's candidacy.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Donald Trump remains a highly influential figure within the Republican Party and has a strong base of support among Republican voters. He announced his candidacy for the 2024 presidential election and has been actively campaigning. Historically, former presidents who seek re-election have a significant advantage in securing their party's nomination due to their established political network and name recognition. Additionally, Trump's ability to dominate media coverage and his continued popularity among a substantial portion of the Republican electorate increases his chances of being the nominee. However, there are potential challenges he faces, including legal issues and competition from other Republican figures who may appeal to different factions within the party. Despite these challenges, the current political landscape suggests that Trump is a frontrunner for the nomination. Given these factors, the probability that Donald Trump will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election is relatively high.

question.title: Will Scotland hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if there is a referendum held in Scotland regarding Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom, and this referendum is held before May 3, 2024.  This referendum may be an "advisory" referendum; that is, it is not necessary for the referendum to have any legally binding effect.

It shall not be deemed resolved by a “wildcat” or “Catalan” style of referendum where the UK government has declined permission for the vote, nor by a vote organised by civil society institutions. A referendum must be deemed to have the consent of the London government

metadata.background_info:
Scotland is one of the UK’s four constituent nations - and its politics are currently dominated by the [Scottish National Party](https://whatscotlandthinks.org/), a party whose core aim is to remove Scotland from the UK and become an independent country. 

The SNP government in Edinburgh previously successfully negotiated with the UK-wide government for the right to hold a referendum, [which took place in 2014](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Scottish_independence_referendum). The “No” side (“Better Together”) won 55% to 45%. The SNP has, however, won every Scottish national election since that date.

The SNP wish to have a fresh vote - stating that Brexit has changed the terms of the argument. The UK government has, to date, refused to countenance permitting such a vote. Under the Scotland Act, the Edinburgh government does not have the power to hold one [without permission.](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1998/46/section/30)

metadata.chain_of_thought: The possibility of Scotland holding an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024, depends on several political and legal factors. Firstly, the Scottish National Party (SNP) has been a strong advocate for a second independence referendum. However, the UK government, led by the Conservative Party, has consistently opposed granting the necessary legal permission for such a referendum. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been no significant changes in the UK government's stance on this issue. Additionally, the process of organizing a referendum requires time for political negotiations, legal preparations, and public campaigning, which further reduces the likelihood of it happening within the given timeframe. Given these considerations, the probability of Scotland holding an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024, seems low.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, Mike Pence is a known political figure who served as Vice President under Donald Trump from 2017 to 2021. However, his chances of becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 Presidential Election face several challenges:

1. **Current Political Climate**: The Republican Party has several potential candidates who are more prominent in the current political landscape. Donald Trump, for example, remains a significant influence within the party and has a strong base of support. Other figures like Ron DeSantis, the Governor of Florida, have also gained considerable attention and support as potential nominees.

2. **Pence's Political Standing**: Mike Pence's relationship with Donald Trump and his base became strained following the 2020 election, particularly due to his role in certifying the election results. This has potentially weakened his appeal among Trump's core supporters, who are a significant faction within the Republican Party.

3. **Polling and Endorsements**: As of the latest available data, Pence has not been leading in Republican primary polls. Candidates like Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis have been performing better in early polls and have received more endorsements from influential figures within the party.

4. **Historical Precedents**: Historically, former Vice Presidents have not always succeeded in securing their party's nomination after their term, especially if they have not maintained a strong independent political presence or base.

5. **Campaign Dynamics**: The dynamics of the primary campaign, including debates, fundraising, and media coverage, will also play a crucial role. Pence would need to significantly outperform expectations in these areas to secure the nomination.

Given these factors, while it is not impossible for Mike Pence to become the Republican nominee, the probability seems low based on the current political environment and the challenges he faces.

question.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.

The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

metadata.background_info:
The 2024 Olympic games is a sporting competition which takes place every four years. It involves a range of different events across multiple sports.

At the Olympic Games, Gold, Silver and Bronze medals are awarded to 1st, 2nd and 3rd place in each event. (In some events two Bronze medals are awarded mostly combat sports).

The US team is one of the most successful teams in recent Olympics, topping the medal table in 2020, 2016, 2012, 2004, 2000. Will they repeat that in 2024?

*Related questions*

* [How many medals will Team USA win in Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7665/total-medals-won-by-the-usa-at-paris-2024/)
* [Will France come in the Top 5 at Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7669/france-home-game-advantage/

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The United States has historically been a dominant force in the Olympic Games, frequently topping the medal table. At the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, the USA was the highest-ranked team, winning 39 gold medals, 41 silver medals, and 33 bronze medals. The country has a strong sporting infrastructure, a large pool of athletes, and significant investment in training and development, which contribute to its consistent performance.

However, there are several factors to consider. The competition is getting tougher, with countries like China, Russia, and Great Britain also investing heavily in their Olympic programs. China, in particular, has been a strong contender, closely trailing the USA in recent Olympics. The host nation, France, may also see a boost in performance due to the home advantage.

Additionally, unforeseen circumstances such as changes in athlete participation, injuries, or geopolitical issues could impact the results. The COVID-19 pandemic has also introduced uncertainties, although by 2024, its impact on the Olympics may be reduced.

Given these considerations, while the USA is likely to be a strong contender for the top spot, the probability is not certain due to the increasing competitiveness of the games.

question.title: Will France place in the Top 5 at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if France place in the top 5 (ties resolve positively) at the Olympics being held in 2024. It will resolve ambiguously if the Olympics do not take place in 2024.

The medal table is calculated by taking the total number of medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medal

metadata.background_info:
*Related Questions on Metaculus:*

* [How many medals will Team USA win at Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7665/total-medals-won-by-the-usa-at-paris-2024/)
* [Will the Team USA top the medal table at Paris 2024?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/7664/usa-most-successful-olympic-team-in-paris/)

----

[There is a phenomenon at the Olympics where by the host country tends to outperform it's recent performances](https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/is-there-home-field-advantage-at-the-olympics/)

France is hosting the Olympics in 2021. Will they place significantly higher in the medal table than they have in recent years. [Their last 6 placings were](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France_at_the_Olympics#Medals_by_Summer_Games):

```
2000: 6th 
2004: 7th 
2008: 10th 
2012: 7th 
2016: 7th
2020: 8th
```

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of France placing in the Top 5 at the 2024 Paris Olympics, we need to consider several factors. Historically, France has been a strong performer in the Olympic Games, often finishing in the top 10 in the medal table. Hosting the Olympics can provide a significant advantage due to increased motivation, familiarity with the environment, and potential for larger team sizes. In the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, France finished 8th in the medal table, which shows they are competitive but not necessarily in the top 5. However, the home advantage could boost their performance significantly. Additionally, France is strong in several sports, including judo, fencing, and cycling, which could contribute to their medal tally. Given these factors, France has a reasonable chance of leveraging the home advantage to improve their standing and potentially finish in the top 5.

question.title: Will BJP form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the BJP has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections.  All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occurring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024)

metadata.background_info:
India has a [parliamentary government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_India) system, with 543 single-member constituencies which use first-past-the-post voting to elect MPs to the [Lok Sabha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha), the lower house in Indian Parliament.  The [Prime Minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India) is appointed by the President and a majority vote of the Lok Sabha; the Prime Minister then leads this governing coalition.  Elections must be held every 5 years, but elections may be called earlier if the President dissolves the Lok Sabha.

The Bhartiya Janata Party (BJP) has been in power at the Union government level since 2014, with [Narendra Modi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi) as Prime Minister, with the Indian National Congress (INC) as the main challenger. The next national elections are scheduled for May 2024.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which party will form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024? (BJP)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the party who has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections.  All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occuring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024)

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has been a dominant force in Indian politics, particularly since Narendra Modi became the Prime Minister in 2014. The BJP has successfully formed the government in the last two general elections (2014 and 2019) with a clear majority. As of the latest data up to October 2023, the BJP continues to be a major political force in India, with strong organizational capabilities, a broad support base, and significant influence in national politics. The party has been able to maintain its popularity through various policy measures, economic reforms, and a strong nationalistic narrative. Additionally, the opposition parties in India have often been fragmented, which has historically benefited the BJP in consolidating its voter base. However, political dynamics can change rapidly, and the outcome of the election will depend on a variety of factors, including economic conditions, the performance of the incumbent government, alliances formed by opposition parties, and regional political dynamics. Despite these uncertainties, the BJP's track record and current political standing suggest a favorable probability of forming the government again in 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The Indian National Congress (INC) has historically been one of the two major political parties in India, but in recent years, its influence has waned significantly. The INC, on the other hand, has struggled to present a strong and cohesive leadership and has faced internal challenges. question.title: Will Russian athletes be barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Russian athletes are barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics under either (i) the Russian flag, (ii) The Russian Olympic Committee's flag, or (iii) any other independent or neutral flag. This will resolve based on the official list of countries and athletes present at the [2024 Olympics](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/paris-2024) or based on credible media reports, indicating that the 2024 Olympics are underway or have concluded without Russian participation. For the question to resolve as **Yes**, no more than 34 Russians can be competing at the 2024 Olympics. 34 was chosen as 10% of [Russian athletes that participated in the 2020 Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Olympic_Committee_athletes_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics) to allow for a few individual or sport specific exceptions.

If more than 34 Russian athletes compete at the 2024 Olympics, this question will resolve as **No**.

If the 2024 Olympics are cancelled or postponed to 2025 or afterwards, this question resolves as ambiguously.

metadata.background_info:
After the [Russian's invasion of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine) in February 2022, Russia has been subject to a large amount of international pressure. That pressure has taken many different forms;  [sanctions](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/10266/russia-sanctions-1-year-after-invasion/), [boycotts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_boycott_of_Russia_and_Belarus), protests, oil and gas embargoes, corporate divestment, and more. Many individuals, corporations, and countries have taking action to show international solidarity with Ukraine.

In the sporting world, Russia has been banned from a number of recent international events. On Feb 28th 2022, four days after Russia invaded, FIFA made an unprecedented decision to [ban Russian clubs and the national team from all competitions](https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/mens/worldcup/qatar2022/media-releases/fifa-uefa-suspend-russian-clubs-and-national-teams-from-all-competitions) including the World Cup.

> Football is fully united here and in full solidarity with all the people affected in Ukraine. Both Presidents [FIFA and UEFA] hope that the situation in Ukraine will improve significantly and rapidly so that football can again be a vector for unity and peace amongst people.

In 2023, the IOC (International Olympic Committee) has reiterated their position several times [[1]](https://olympics.com/ioc/news/q-a-on-solidarity-with-ukraine-sanctions-against-russia-and-belarus-and-the-status-of-athletes-from-these-countries)[[2]](https://olympics.com/ioc/news/q-a-on-solidarity-with-ukraine-sanctions-against-russia-and-belarus-and-the-status-of-athletes-from-these-countries) that Russian and Belarusian athletes can only compete as Individual Neutral Athletes.

Despite IOC recommendations Poland banned Russian and Belarusian athletes from [the 2023 European Games](https://notesfrompoland.com/2023/03/29/russians-and-belarusians-banned-from-european-games-in-poland-despite-ioc-recommendations/). In Paris, the 2024 Olympic host city,  event organizers [cancelled a World Cup fencing event](https://apnews.com/article/fencing-france-russia-ukraine-2821983e726628c8bbf21e1eb8dd8c76) after the FIE (International Fencing Federation) [decision](https://apnews.com/article/fencing-russia-ukraine-olympics-9754e17d554df4484c609248019bd1a9) to allow Russian athletes to resume competing one year after the invasion of Ukraine. 

Looking back at previous Olympics, Russia's Track and Field team was [barred from the 2016 Olympics](https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/18/sports/olympics/russia-barred-rio-summer-olympics-doping.html) over a decade long doping scandal. 68 Athletes filled appeals that were ultimately [dismissed by the Court of Arbitration for Sport](https://www.nbcsports.com/bayarea/russians-lose-track-appeal-ioc-weigh-total-ban-rio), though [some](https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1133394/russia-ana-athletics) Russian athletes were able to compete as 'Authorized Neutral Athletes'. At the 2016 Paralympics the entire Russian Paralympic team was banned over the same doping scandal.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: The participation of Russian athletes in international competitions, including the Olympics, has been a contentious issue due to geopolitical tensions and doping scandals. Historically, Russian athletes have faced restrictions, such as competing under a neutral flag, due to state-sponsored doping allegations. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has taken steps to ensure fair competition, which has included barring athletes from countries with systemic doping issues. As of the last update, there is no blanket ban on Russian athletes for the 2024 Olympics. However, the situation is fluid and could change based on geopolitical developments, particularly related to the ongoing conflict involving Russia. The IOC's decisions are influenced by political pressures, international relations, and the need to uphold the integrity of the Games. Given the criteria for the question to resolve as YES—no more than 34 Russian athletes competing under any flag—there remains a possibility of a significant restriction being placed on Russian athletes. However, unless there is a significant escalation in international pressure or new revelations related to doping, it is more likely that Russian athletes will be allowed to compete, albeit possibly under a neutral flag, as was the case in previous Olympics. Considering these factors, while there is a non-negligible chance of a severe restriction being imposed, the probability of Russian athletes being completely barred or limited to such a small number is relatively low.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

All other candidates will resolve as **No**.  This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Tim Scott is one of several candidates vying for the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election. The field includes high-profile figures such as former President Donald Trump, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, and former Vice President Mike Pence, among others. Historically, the Republican nomination tends to favor candidates with significant name recognition, strong fundraising capabilities, and broad support within the party. While Tim Scott is a sitting U.S. Senator with a notable profile, he does not currently have the same level of national prominence or polling support as some of the frontrunners like Trump or DeSantis. Additionally, Trump's influence within the Republican Party remains substantial, and he has consistently shown strong polling numbers among Republican voters. Given these factors, while it's possible for Scott to gain traction, the probability of him securing the nomination over more prominent and better-funded candidates appears relatively low at this time.

question.title: Will S&D hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the S&D holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.background_info:
The [European Parliament](https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/government_in_ireland/european_government/eu_institutions/european_parliament.html#:~:text=The%20European%20Parliament%20is%20part,member%20states%20every%205%20years.) is a key legislative body within the European Union (EU) that shares lawmaking responsibilities with the Council of the European Union. Comprising [705](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/faq/11/how-many-meps) directly elected Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) from EU member states, the Parliament holds elections every five years. While it cannot initiate legislation, the European Parliament can approve, reject, or amend proposed laws, and it also supervises EU institutions and budgets.

During [European parliamentary elections](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/at-your-service/en/be-heard/elections), candidates run as representatives of their national parties, which are typically affiliated with political groups in the European Parliament. Once elected, Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) officially join political groups based on shared ideologies and policy objectives that align with their national parties. According to the [EU Parliament website](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/about-parliament/en/organisation-and-rules/organisation/political-groups), the following political groups are currently present in the European parliament:

| Group Name | Abbreviation |
|------------|--------------|
| Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) | EPP |
| Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament | S&D |
| Renew Europe Group | RE |
| Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance | Greens/EFA |
| Identity and Democracy Group | ID |
| European Conservatives and Reformists Group | ECR |
| The Left group in the European Parliament  | GUE/NGL |

In the [2019 elections](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/election-results-2019/en), the seats were allocated as follows between the political groups: 

| Group Name | Abbreviation | Seats |
|------------|--------------|-------|
| Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) | EPP | 182 |
| Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament | S&D | 154 |
| Renew Europe Group | RE | 108 |
| Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance | Greens/EFA | 74 |
| Identity and Democracy Group | ID | 73 |
| European Conservatives and Reformists Group | ECR | 62 |
| Non-Inscrits | NI | 57 |
| Confederal Group of the European United Left - Nordic Green Left | GUE/NGL | 41 |
| **Total Seats** | | **751** |


The next European parliamentary elections are [scheduled for 2024](https://multimedia.europarl.europa.eu/en/package/european-elections-2024_23001), with [polling](https://europeelects.eu/ep2024/) indicating a narrow lead for the EPP in early 2023.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Socialists and Democrats (S&D) group is one of the major political groups in the European Parliament. Historically, the European People's Party (EPP) has often held the most seats, with the S&D typically being the second-largest group. The political landscape in Europe is dynamic, with various factors influencing election outcomes, such as economic conditions, migration issues, and public sentiment towards the European Union. Recent trends have shown a rise in support for other political groups, such as the Greens and far-right parties, which could dilute the share of seats for both the EPP and S&D. Additionally, the S&D's performance can be affected by the political situation in key member states like Germany, France, and Italy, where national elections and political shifts could influence the European Parliamentary elections. Considering these factors, while S&D is a strong contender, it is historically less likely to surpass the EPP in terms of seats, barring significant political changes or shifts in voter sentiment leading up to the elections.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability of Renew holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors. Renew Europe is a centrist political group in the European Parliament, formed from the merger of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE) and Emmanuel Macron's La République En Marche! (LREM) party, among others. Historically, the two largest groups in the European Parliament have been the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). In the 2019 elections, Renew Europe was the third-largest group, behind the EPP and S&D.

To become the largest group, Renew would need to significantly increase its number of seats, while the EPP and S&D would need to lose seats. This outcome would require major shifts in voter preferences across multiple EU countries, potentially driven by significant political or economic developments. Additionally, the European Parliament elections are influenced by national politics, and Renew's performance would depend on its constituent parties' success in their respective countries.

Considering these factors, while it is possible for Renew to increase its seat count, it is unlikely that it will surpass both the EPP and S&D to become the largest group. Therefore, the probability of Renew holding the most seats after the 2024 elections is relatively low.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The Greens–European Free Alliance (Greens–EFA) is a political group in the European Parliament that traditionally focuses on environmental issues, social justice, and human rights. Historically, they have not been the largest political group in the European Parliament. The largest groups have typically been the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D), which are more centrist and have broader appeal across the EU member states.

For the Greens–EFA to hold the most seats after the 2024 elections, there would need to be a significant shift in voter sentiment across Europe towards green and progressive policies. While environmental issues have gained prominence, it is unlikely that this will translate into the Greens–EFA overtaking the traditionally larger parties. Additionally, the political landscape in Europe is diverse, with many countries having strong national parties that align with other European political groups.

Furthermore, the electoral system for the European Parliament is proportional, which tends to favor larger, established parties that can garner widespread support across multiple countries. While the Greens–EFA may increase their seat count, surpassing both the EPP and S&D would require an unprecedented level of support.

Given these factors, the probability of the Greens–EFA holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections is low.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Which political group will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections? (GUE-NGL)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** for the political group that holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The GUE/NGL (European United Left–Nordic Green Left) is a political group in the European Parliament that traditionally represents left-wing and far-left parties. Historically, this group has not held the majority of seats in the European Parliament. The largest groups have typically been the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D), with other groups like Renew Europe and the Greens/EFA also holding significant numbers of seats. 

As of the latest data available before the 2024 elections, GUE/NGL holds a relatively small proportion of the total seats compared to these larger groups. For GUE/NGL to hold the most seats after the 2024 elections, there would need to be a significant shift in the political landscape across EU member states, with a substantial increase in support for left-wing and far-left parties. While political shifts can occur, particularly in response to social, economic, or environmental issues, the likelihood of GUE/NGL surpassing all other groups, including historically dominant ones like EPP and S&D, is low.

Additionally, the political climate and trends leading up to 2024 do not strongly indicate a major surge for the GUE/NGL that would enable them to surpass the larger centrist and right-wing parties in terms of seats. Therefore, based on historical trends and current political dynamics, it is unlikely that GUE/NGL will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections.

question.title: Will Linda Yaccarino be the CEO of Twitter on July 1, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Linda Yaccarino is in the position of CEO at Twitter on July 1, 2024, according to official announcements from Twitter or credible media sources.

metadata.background_info:
Linda Yaccarino, the former advertising chief of NBCUniversal, has been [appointed as the CEO of Twitter](https://edition.cnn.com/2023/05/12/tech/twitter-ceo-linda-yaccarino/index.html) by Elon Musk, the owner of the platform. She's expected to [assume the role in late June, 2023](https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1656748197308674048). The selection of Yaccarino indicates Musk's focus on Twitter's advertising business and his plans to revamp the social network into  [X, the “everything app”](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/may/11/elon-musk-twitter-new-ceo).  Yaccarino has a strong background in the advertising industry and is known for her influential role in Madison Avenue.

Assuming the role of Twitter CEO, Yaccarino will face various challenges, including Twitter's struggles to expand its advertising business, gaps in expertise and technical glitches, and the company's substantial debt. Additionally, she will have to navigate the unpredictable nature of working with Musk.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: Linda Yaccarino was appointed as the CEO of Twitter (now rebranded as X) in May 2023, following Elon Musk's decision to step down from the role. Her appointment was seen as a strategic move to leverage her advertising expertise to revitalize Twitter's revenue streams. The likelihood of her remaining in the position by July 1, 2024, depends on several factors:

1. **Performance and Company Strategy**: If Yaccarino successfully implements strategies that improve Twitter's financial performance and user engagement, her position as CEO is likely to be secure. However, if the company continues to face financial difficulties or fails to meet strategic goals, there could be pressure for leadership changes.

2. **Elon Musk's Influence**: As the owner of Twitter, Elon Musk has significant influence over the company's leadership decisions. If he is satisfied with Yaccarino's performance and the direction she is taking the company, she is more likely to remain CEO. Conversely, Musk's history of making abrupt changes could lead to her replacement if he feels a change is warranted.

3. **Industry Trends and Competition**: The social media landscape is highly competitive and subject to rapid changes. If Twitter faces increased competition or regulatory challenges, this could impact leadership stability.

4. **External Factors**: Factors such as economic conditions, shifts in advertising trends, or major public relations issues could also influence her tenure.

Considering these factors, while there is inherent uncertainty, the typical tenure for a CEO, especially one appointed to drive significant change, often extends beyond a year unless there are major issues. Therefore, the probability of Linda Yaccarino remaining CEO until July 1, 2024, seems reasonably favorable.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

metadata.background_info:
From [Reuters on May 24, 2023](https://www.reuters.com/technology/openai-may-leave-eu-if-regulations-bite-ceo-2023-05-24), "OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said on Wednesday the ChatGPT maker might consider leaving Europe if it could not comply with the upcoming artificial intelligence (AI) regulations by the European Union."

The [EU AI Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence_Act) "regulates the providers of artificial intelligence systems, and entities making use of them in a professional capacity." As of May 24, 2024, [Metaculus expects](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8787/passing-of-the-ai-act/) the AI Act to be passed between Oct 2023 and Nov 2024, with a median of April 2024, though OpenAI could choose to cease offering ChatGPT in Europe earlier than that, or for some other reason entirely.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of the latest information available, OpenAI's ChatGPT has been broadly accessible in the European Union (EU) and only faced temporary restrictions in specific countries like Italy due to regulatory compliance issues. OpenAI has shown a willingness to address regulatory concerns, as evidenced by their swift response to the Italian data protection authority's demands in early 2023. Given this precedent, it is reasonable to expect that OpenAI will continue to work to ensure compliance with EU regulations and maintain general availability of ChatGPT in the region. Additionally, OpenAI's ongoing efforts to expand and improve their services suggest a commitment to maintaining access across major markets, including the EU. Therefore, it is likely that ChatGPT will be generally available in the EU by June 30, 2024, barring unforeseen regulatory changes or compliance issues.

question.title: Will Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

These figures have significantly more national recognition, political experience, and influence within the party. Additionally, the Republican nomination process tends to favor candidates with established political networks and significant fundraising capabilities, which Elder may lack in comparison to the frontrunners. Given these factors, while it is not impossible for Larry Elder to become the nominee, it is highly unlikely.

question.title: Will Anthropic publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, Anthropic publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.background_info:
On July 21, 2023, the White House announced ([fact sheet](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2023/07/21/fact-sheet-biden-harris-administration-secures-voluntary-commitments-from-leading-artificial-intelligence-companies-to-manage-the-risks-posed-by-ai/), [full report](https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Ensuring-Safe-Secure-and-Trustworthy-AI.pdf)) that Amazon, Anthropic, Google, Inflection, Meta, Microsoft, and OpenAI have voluntarily committed to manage AI risks.

The voluntary commitments are in three categories (a) "Ensuring Products are Safe Before Introducing Them to the Public", (b) "Building Systems that Put Security First", and (c) "Earning the Public’s Trust", and are "designed to advance a generative AI legal and policy regime".

From [Microsoft](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/openai/concepts/red-teaming), "historically described systematic adversarial attacks for testing security vulnerabilities. With the rise of LLMs, the term has extended beyond traditional cybersecurity and evolved in common usage to describe many kinds of probing, testing, and attacking of AI systems." Note that this question only asks about _safety_, not _security_. [Google](https://bughunters.google.com/about/rules/6625378258649088/google-and-alphabet-vulnerability-reward-program-vrp-rules) and [OpenAI](https://bugcrowd.com/openai) already have bug bounties for security.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Will these AI labs publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024? (Anthropic)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body: For each AI lab, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Anthropic is a company that has shown a commitment to AI safety and transparency. They have previously engaged with the AI community on safety issues and have a track record of publishing research and findings related to AI safety. The concept of red-teaming, which involves stress-testing systems to identify vulnerabilities, is increasingly recognized as a best practice in AI development, especially for ensuring safety and robustness. Given the growing emphasis on AI safety and external validation, it is plausible that Anthropic would engage in such activities and report on them publicly. However, the timeline for such activities can be uncertain, and there might be strategic or operational reasons that could delay or prevent the publication of such a report. Nevertheless, considering the company's past behavior and the industry's trend towards transparency, there is a reasonable probability that they will publish a report by the specified date.

question.title: Will Meta publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, Meta publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.background_info:
On July 21, 2023, the White House announced ([fact sheet](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2023/07/21/fact-sheet-biden-harris-administration-secures-voluntary-commitments-from-leading-artificial-intelligence-companies-to-manage-the-risks-posed-by-ai/), [full report](https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Ensuring-Safe-Secure-and-Trustworthy-AI.pdf)) that Amazon, Anthropic, Google, Inflection, Meta, Microsoft, and OpenAI have voluntarily committed to manage AI risks.

The voluntary commitments are in three categories (a) "Ensuring Products are Safe Before Introducing Them to the Public", (b) "Building Systems that Put Security First", and (c) "Earning the Public’s Trust", and are "designed to advance a generative AI legal and policy regime".

From [Microsoft](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-services/openai/concepts/red-teaming), "historically described systematic adversarial attacks for testing security vulnerabilities. With the rise of LLMs, the term has extended beyond traditional cybersecurity and evolved in common usage to describe many kinds of probing, testing, and attacking of AI systems." Note that this question only asks about _safety_, not _security_. [Google](https://bughunters.google.com/about/rules/6625378258649088/google-and-alphabet-vulnerability-reward-program-vrp-rules) and [OpenAI](https://bugcrowd.com/openai) already have bug bounties for security.

reformat_metaculus_question.original_question: Will these AI labs publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024? (Meta)
reformat_metaculus_question.original_body: For each AI lab, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Meta, as a leading technology company, has been under increasing scrutiny regarding the safety and ethical implications of its AI models. The company has a vested interest in demonstrating its commitment to safety and transparency, especially given past criticisms over privacy and data handling. Conducting external red-teaming is a recognized method for assessing and improving the safety of AI models. Publishing the results of such evaluations can enhance public trust and showcase Meta's dedication to responsible AI development. Moreover, Meta has previously engaged in transparency efforts, such as releasing transparency reports and sharing research findings. However, there are factors that could influence the likelihood of publication, such as the potential negative findings from the red-teaming exercise, internal strategic decisions, or unforeseen delays. Given the current trends and pressures for transparency in AI development, it is plausible that Meta would publish such a report by the specified date.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024?
question.body: The question resolves **Yes** if Donald Trump is charged or indicted for any statements related to potential witnesses in *[The State of Georgia v. Donald J. Trump, et al](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_Georgia)*. The indictments must occur before June 1, 2024.

metadata.background_info:
On August 14, 2023, former President Donald Trump was [indicted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_Georgia#Indictment) by a grand jury in Georgia, alongside 18 other individuals. The state brought charges against Trump related to Trump's alleged participation in an attempt to overturn the state's 2020 presidential election results.

Trump made statements on his social media platform, Truth Social, which [appeared to warn](https://www.axios.com/2023/08/14/trump-witness-tampering-georgia-indictment) potential witnesses not to testify against him.

> Former President Donald Trump posted on Truth Social, his social media platform, on Monday saying Georgia’s former Lt. Gov. Geoff Duncan “shouldn’t” testify in grand jury proceedings this week regarding allegations that Trump attempted to overturn the 2020 election results in the state—and some legal analysts are saying the post could be witness intimidation or tampering.

> ...

> Per Georgia law, anyone who attempts to [influence](https://law.justia.com/codes/georgia/2020/title-16/chapter-10/article-5/section-16-10-93/) a witness is subject to felony charges and, if convicted, can face one to five years in prison; anyone who [threatens](https://law.justia.com/codes/georgia/2022/title-16/chapter-10/article-2/section-16-10-32/#:~:text=Attempted%20Murder%20or%20Threatening%20of%20Witnesses%20in%20Official%20Proceedings,-Universal%20Citation%3A%20GA&text=shall%20be%20guilty%20of%20a,nor%20more%20than%2020%20years.) a witness is subject to felony charges and, if convicted, faces 10 to 20 years in prison. ([Forbes](https://www.forbes.com/sites/mollybohannon/2023/08/14/trump-suggested-a-witness-shouldnt-testify-in-georgias-grand-jury-proceedings-critics-say-thats-witness-intimidation/?sh=7e14b52a57be))

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability of Donald Trump being charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024, we need to consider several factors:

1. **Current Legal Context**: As of October 2023, Donald Trump is facing multiple legal challenges, including the high-profile case in Georgia. The case involves allegations related to attempts to overturn the 2020 election results in Georgia. Witness tampering could potentially be a charge if there is evidence of Trump attempting to influence or intimidate witnesses involved in this case.

2. **Evidence and Investigation**: For a charge of witness tampering to be filed, there must be substantial evidence that Trump made statements or took actions intended to influence or intimidate witnesses. The ongoing investigation and legal proceedings might uncover such evidence, but it is speculative to predict its existence without insider knowledge.

3. **Legal and Political Considerations**: The decision to charge Trump with witness tampering would involve both legal judgments and political considerations. Prosecutors would need to weigh the strength of the evidence against the potential political ramifications of charging a former president.

4. **Historical Precedent**: Historically, charging a high-profile political figure with witness tampering is rare and would require clear and compelling evidence. However, given the unprecedented nature of the legal proceedings against Trump, historical precedent may be less predictive.

5. **Timeline**: The resolution of this question depends on the timeline of the legal process. The deadline of June 1, 2024, is relatively close, and legal processes can be slow, especially in complex cases involving high-profile defendants.

Considering these factors, while there is a non-zero probability that Trump could be charged with witness tampering, the combination of needing strong evidence, the political implications, and the relatively short timeline makes it less likely than not.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.background_info:
*This question is modeled on [this Metaculus question](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/18606/trump-removed-or-blocked-from-the-ballot/), but asks instead about the possibility of Trump's removal from primary election ballots.*

The 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution has a section known as the "Disqualification Clause" or Section 3, which may disqualify individuals from holding federal or state office if they have "engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the [U.S.], or given aid or comfort to the enemies thereof." Given the events surrounding the January 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, this section has become a subject of considerable debate with respect to former President Donald Trump's eligibility to run for federal office again.

In New Hampshire, Bryant "Corky" Messner, an attorney who ran for U.S. Senate in 2020 with Trump's endorsement, has [expressed intentions to file a legal challenge](https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisondurkee/2023/08/29/trump-14th-amendment-new-hampshire-gop-feuds-as-states-grapple-with-disqualifying-trump-from-ballot/?sh=70038b512e9a) questioning Trump's 2024 candidacy under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The Republican Secretary of State of New Hampshire, David Scanlan, while not actively seeking to remove any candidates, has stated that he will seek legal advice on the issue. Additionally, Michigan’s Democratic Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson has indicated that she will seek a legal opinion on this matter. Voters have also filed lawsuits in Florida and Michigan on the issue. Legal battles are widely expected, and these disputes might reach the U.S. Supreme Court.

This question focuses on whether these and similar ongoing discussions and legal challenges will result in Donald Trump being removed from the primary election ballot of any state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15th, 2024, the planned start of the 2024 Republican National Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The question revolves around whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, often referred to as the "Disqualification Clause," bars individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding office. The potential application of this clause to Donald Trump has been a topic of legal and political debate, especially following the events of January 6, 2021.

Several factors need to be considered:

1. Legal Precedent and Challenges: There is limited precedent for the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment in modern times. Any attempt to remove Trump from the ballot would likely face significant legal challenges, potentially reaching the Supreme Court. Such legal processes can be lengthy and complex.

2. Political Considerations: The decision to remove a major political figure like Trump from the ballot would have significant political ramifications. State officials, particularly in Republican-leaning states, may be hesitant to take such a step unless there is overwhelming legal justification.

3. Current Legal Actions: As of now, there have been discussions and some legal filings attempting to use the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump, but no state has officially removed him from a ballot. The resolution of these cases is uncertain and may not occur before July 15, 2024.

4. Public and Political Pressure: There may be pressure from various groups either supporting or opposing Trump's candidacy, which could influence the actions of state officials and courts.

Given these considerations, while it is possible that a state could attempt to remove Trump from the ballot under the 14th Amendment, the combination of legal, political, and procedural hurdles makes it relatively unlikely that such an action would be finalized and upheld by July 15, 2024.

question.title: Will Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, [saying at a rally in March 2022](https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-promises-to-return-to-the-white-house-in-2024-2022-3), "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before".  [Early polling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.  

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of [June 2022](https://floridapolitics.com/archives/531919-ron-desantis-swats-away-2024-speculation-yet-again/)), though Fox News producers have [called him](https://www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/08/13/inside-fox-news-desantis-is-the-future-of-the-party-and-hes-taking-advantage/) "the future of the Republican Party".  DeSantis is a frequent [second-place favorite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election#Republican_Party_2) in polling behind Trump.

Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; [in April 2022](https://archive.ph/uFSD4), when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

Reasoning: Glenn Youngkin, the Governor of Virginia, is a prominent figure in the Republican Party and has garnered attention as a potential presidential candidate. However, as of the latest data up to October 2023, the Republican primary race for the 2024 presidential election is dominated by well-established figures such as former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis. Trump, in particular, has a strong base of support within the Republican Party and has consistently led in early polls. DeSantis is also considered a strong contender with significant national recognition and support.

Youngkin's political profile is rising, especially after his 2021 gubernatorial win in Virginia, which was seen as a significant victory for Republicans. He has a moderate image and could appeal to a broad spectrum of Republican voters. However, he has not declared his candidacy for the presidency, and there are no strong indications that he will enter the race imminently. The Republican National Convention will ultimately decide the nominee, and the process is highly competitive, typically favoring candidates with extensive national political networks and established support.

Given the current political landscape, the presence of strong contenders like Trump and DeSantis, and the lack of definitive moves from Youngkin to enter the race, the probability of him being the Republican nominee remains relatively low. However, political dynamics can change, and new developments could alter the probability as we approach the convention.

question.title: Will Real Madrid win the 2023/2024 UEFA Champions League?
question.body: The question resolves "Yes" if Real Madrid wins the Final on the 1st of June 2024, according to [UEFA](https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/). All other teams resolve "No".

metadata.background_info: [The UEFA Champions League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League) (previously known as the European Cup, abbreviated as UCL, or sometimes, UEFA CL) is an annual club association football competition organised by the Union of European Football Associations (UEFA) and contested by top-division European clubs, deciding the competition winners through a round robin group stage to qualify for a double-legged knockout format, and a single leg final. The 2023/24 edition features 32 teams, with the final being played on the 1st of June 2024 at Wembley Stadium.
